Applet on circles and ellipses: http: //mathinsite.bmth.ac.uk/applet/ellipses/ellipses.html 2. Applet on graphs of various functions: http: //www.analyzemath.com/ Introduction For concept learning systems, graphical data representation is crucial. A good representation might make possible the learning of a concept that was not learnable using other representations. For example, in the case of the earthquake domain (earthquake data such as its location, epicenter, intensity, depth, type, etc.), we need important information such as the distance between the earthquakes’ epicentres and the difference in time between the earthquakes. This information could make possible the learning of an important concept. This is known as a graph-based concept learning system. Below are some examples of “graphs” you see in physical world.
 474  Chapter 6. Example 8 Find the stationary point(s) of the graph 2251 5 1 3.32xxyxx Solution: Using GC, the maximum point is (1.50, -7).
 524  Chapter 3 (Pure Mathematics): Exponential and Logarithmic Functions Objectives At the end of the chapter, you should be able to: (a) understand the characteristics of the indices; (b) understand the characteristics of the exponential and logarithmic functions, ex and lnx (c) understand that exy and lnxy are equivalent statements; (d) understand the nature of exponential growth and decay; (e) solve simple exponential and logarithmic equations; Content 1.1 Indices 1.1.1 Laws of Indices 1.1.2 Exponential Equations 1.2 A Particular Exponential Functions 1.3 Logarithmic functions 1.3.1 Definition of a Logarithm 1.3.2 Laws of Logarithm 1.4 Solving Miscellaneous Equations References New Syllabus Additional Mathematics (8th Edition), Shinglee Publishers Pte Ltd. Introduction There are many real life applications that use logarithm, from finding the time to reach an investment goal to modeling many natural processes, particularly in living systems. We perceive loudness of sound as the logarithm of the actual sound intensity, and dB (decibels) is a logarithmic scale. We also perceive brightness of light as the logarithm of the actual light energy, and star magnitudes are measured on a logarithmic scale. Most interesting of all could be the measurement of earthquake intensity on the Richter scale. The Richter magnitudes are based on a logarithmic scale (base 10). What this means is that for each whole number you go up on the Richter scale, the amplitude of the ground motion recorded by a seismograph goes up ten times. Using this scale, a magnitude 5 earthquake would result in ten times the level of ground shaking as a magnitude 4 earthquake. Magnitude of an earthquake is logIMS where I is the intensity of the earthquake (measured by the amplitude of a seismograph reading taken 100 km from the epicenter of the earthquake) and S is the intensity of a ''standard earthquake'' (whose amplitude is 1 micron =10-4 cm).

[L23] Correlation and Linear Regression Page 3 of 59
[L24] 7.1 Introduction
[L25] Regression analysis and correlation analysis have been developed to study and measure the 
[L26] statistical relationship that exists between two or more variables. In the A Level syllabus, we 
[L27] will investigate the linear regression analysis and linear correlation analysis of two variables. 
[L28] In linear correlation analysis, we measure the strength or closeness of the linear relationship 
[L29] between the two variables. 
[L30] In linear regression analysis, we prepare an estimating (or regression) linear equation to 
[L31] estimate the values of one variable from given values of another. 
[L32] In other words, correlation analysis reveals the extent to which two variables are related
[L33] whilst regression analysis tells us how they are related.
[L34] EXAMPLE
[L35] We are interested in the relationship between the number of hours studying and the marks 
[L36] obtained. The table below shows the amount of time (x hours) that 6 average students spent 
[L37] studying for a test and the marks that they obtained (y out of 100 marks). 
[L38] x 1 2.5 3 4 4.2 5
[L39] y 20 46 48 60 61 65
[L40] Correlation and regression analyses will help us to answer the following questions:
[L41]  Is there a relationship between the amount of time spent on revision and marks 
[L42] obtained? – Correlation
[L43]  Is the relationship a linear one? – Linear Correlation
[L44]  If there is a linear relationship, can we reasonably predict the value of one of the 
[L45] variables from the knowledge of the other? – By finding the regression line
[L46]  If another student studies for 2 hours, can you predict how many marks he will obtain? 
[L47] What about if he studies for 7 hours? – By using the regression line
[L48]  How certain are you of your prediction? – Interpolation, Extrapolation
[L49] 7.1.1 Bivariate Data
[L50] Bivariate data refers to data connecting two variables. Each observation thus comprises a pair 
[L51] of values taken by the two variables. It is customary to express the bivariate data as ordered 
[L52] pairs (x, y).

[L49] 1.1 BASIC COUNTING PRINCIPLES
[L50] In the process of solving a counting problem, there are two very simple but basic principles 
[L51] that we always apply. They are called the Addition Principle and Multiplication Principle.
[L52] 1.1.1 The Addition Principle (OR)
[L53] Suppose you want to buy an ice cream. You have 5 flavours to choose from: Chocolate OR 
[L54] strawberry OR vanilla OR oreo OR mint. How many choices do you have?
[L55] Answer: 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 5 
[L56]  Chocolate OR strawberry OR vanilla OR oreo OR mint
[L57] In general, if there exists k non-overlapping categories of ways to perform an operation and 
[L58] the first category can be done in n1 ways, the second in n2 ways, …., the kth category in nk
[L59] ways, then the operation can be done in 1 2 ... k nn n   ways.
[L60] 1.1.2 The Multiplication Principle (AND)
[L61] Suppose you want to buy an ice cream on a cone. There are 5 ice cream flavours to choose 
[L62] from and there are 3 types of cones. How many different choices do you have?
[L63] No. of ways to choose a cone = 3
[L64] No.

content.text:
bash -lc python - <<'PY'
import re
from pathlib import Path
import PyPDF2

pdf_path = Path('/mnt/data/H1 Mathematics A Level Notes-edited.pdf')
reader = PyPDF2.PdfReader(str(pdf_path))

chapter_re = re.compile(r'Chapter\s*\d+\s*(?:\([^)]*\))?\s*[:]?\s*[^\n\r]+', re.IGNORECASE)
check_re = re.compile(r'Check your Understanding\s*\([^)]*\)', re.IGNORECASE)


def norm(s: str) -> str:
    # normalize whitespace and punctuation
    s = s.replace('\u2019', "'")
    s = re.sub(r'\s+', ' ', s).strip()
    # remove trailing page markers like 'Page 1 of 20'
    s = re.sub(r'\s+Page\s+\d+\s+of\s+\d+\s*$', '', s, flags=re.IGNORECASE)
    # remove trailing standalone digits (chapter internal page numbers)
    # e.g. 'Chapter 6 : Hypothesis Testing 1'
    s = re.sub(r'(Chapter\s*\d+\s*[:]?\s*[^\d]+)\s+\d+\s*$', r'\1', s, flags=re.IGNORECASE)
    # fix spacing around colon
    s = re.sub(r'\s*:\s*', ': ', s)
    s = re.sub(r'\s*\(\s*', ' (', s)
    s = re.sub(r'\s*\)\s*', ')', s)
    return s

headings = {}

for idx, page in enumerate(reader.pages):
    try:
        text = page.extract_text() or ''
    except Exception:
        continue
    # Only scan first 25 lines to avoid matching exercises etc
    lines = text.splitlines()[:25]
    for line in lines:
        if 'Chapter' in line:
            for m in chapter_re.finditer(line):
                h = norm(m.group(0))
                headings.setdefault(h, idx+1)
        if 'Check your Understanding' in line:
            for m in check_re.finditer(line):
                h = norm(m.group(0))
                headings.setdefault(h, idx+1)

# Now filter obvious junk headings (too long)
filtered = {}
for h, p in headings.items():
    if len(h) > 120:
        continue
    # skip 'Chapter 6:' lines that are actually within examples (no title)
    if re.match(r'^Chapter\s*\d+\s*:\s*\.?\s*$', h, re.IGNORECASE):
        continue
    filtered[h] = p

# Sort by page number
items = sorted(filtered.items(), key=lambda kv: (kv[1], kv[0].lower()))
print('Total headings (filtered):', len(items))
for h, p in items:
    print(f'{p:>3}  {h}')

PY
